displaytitle: Nose pipe in the form of a kneeling human
medium: Ceramic with brown slip and red pigment

titles.title: Nose pipe in the form of a kneeling human

texts.textentryhtml: This humanoid vessel was most likely used to snuff tobacco or some other psychotropic substance. The chest of the figure held the powdered substance, and the rounded spout on top of the head was inserted into the user's nostril. The large, round nostrils of the upturned nose seem to echo the function of the vessel. The placement of the conical snout on the head may also refer to the object's use; comparable conical "horns" on later ceramic figurines from Colima have been interpreted as references to the shamanic capacity to interact with the supernatural world through the use of hallucinogenic intoxicants. Some of the stylized elements in this piece result from functional requirements, but other aspects may indicate the spread of artistic conventions from the Olmec. By 1400 B.C., the nearby site of Teopantecuanitlan exhibited strong connections with the Gulf Coast Olmec, who may have exposed Xochipala to Olmec stylization, a possibility suggested most strongly by the geometric patterns in the hair of the figure.
Howard H. Scott, West Palm Beach, FL; purchased by the Princeton University Art Museum, 1991.
